name: stress-ng
description: Stress test a computer system in various selectable ways

repo.name: stress-ng
repo.description: This is the stress-ng upstream project git repository.  stress-ng will stress test a computer system in various selectable ways. It was designed to exercise various physical subsystems of a computer as well as the various operating system kernel interfaces.

readme.summary: Excellent clarity and build instructions but lacks practical usage examples and configuration documentation for actually running stress tests.
readme.top_issue: No examples showing how to actually use stress-ng beyond --help; missing documentation on command-line options, how to run specific tests, or interpret results

injection_risks.description: The stress_mk_filename function is used to construct a filename, but it does not appear to be vulnerable to injection attacks as the input parameters are controlled by the program.
The stress_apparmor_read function opens a file using the open system call, but the filename is constructed using the stress_mk_filename function which appears to be safe.
The stress_apparmor_dir function opens a directory using the opendir system call, but the directory name is constructed using the stress_mk_filename function which appears to be safe.

critical_findings: Potential for denial of service attacks due to unvalidated system calls.
Potential for information disclosure due to error messages containing sensitive information.
security.summary: The stress-apparmor.c code has some potential security issues, including unvalidated system calls and hardcoded buffer sizes, but overall it appears to be a relatively secure program.

common_complaints: Build failures with specific compiler flags
sentiment.summary: stress-ng demonstrates healthy community engagement with active maintainers addressing technical issues, though users encounter platform-specific bugs and occasional documentation gaps that create minor friction.

communication.summary: The maintainer's responses are consistently helpful, clear, patient, and technically sound, making them an exemplary model for open-source project maintainers.

concerns: No commits in past 6 months despite last commit being today
Zero active contributors in past 6 months
No merged pull requests in past 6 months
No closed issues in past 6 months
1 open issue with no recent activity
maintenance.summary: stress-ng shows signs of stagnation with no development activity, contributor engagement, or issue resolution over the past 6 months, indicating minimal active maintenance.

analysis_summary.doc_summary: The README provides detailed installation and build instructions, but lacks clear configuration and troubleshooting guidance.
concerns: Community: unexpected behavior on specific architectures
Security: Potential for denial of service attacks due to unvalidated system calls.
Security: Potential for information disclosure due to error messages containing sensitive information.
High bus factor risk (98% from top contributor)
highlights: High number of commits in the past 6 months (1000)
Recent last commit and release dates
Multiple contributors active in the past 6 months (7)
Closed issues and merged PRs indicate active issue resolution
